Our SLA requires the end‑to‑end communication service to be available 99 percent of the time in the metro area.
We are aiming for a yearly availability target of at least 99.5 % for the 5G voice service across the region.
The service must be up almost all the time, allowing only a few minutes of downtime per month.
Please configure the new network slice so that it is only accessible in Greece (country code GR).
We need the slice to serve the Benelux market; ensure it is available in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.
Our enterprise customers require coverage across all EU member states where we have roaming agreements, except the United Kingdom; provide the full list of applicable country codes.
Please provision the service for the whole of France; for the Area of Service attribute this means using the region identifier 0.
The rollout will be limited to the northern and central provinces of Italy, which correspond to region IDs 1 and 2 in our internal list.

Our customer only needs connectivity in the metropolitan area around the capital and the adjacent coastal strip; according to our mapping for the listed country those zones are represented by region identifiers 0, 2 and 3.
We need the slice to operate at a minimum altitude of 500 meters across the entire service area.
For the mountainous region, ensure the network slice supports a floor altitude that's at least 1.2 kilometers above sea level.
Our coverage area includes the Alpine zone, where the tallest peak reaches 2,300 m; the slice must maintain a minimum service altitude 200 m higher than any ground elevation.
Enable delay‑tolerant mode for the firmware‑upgrade traffic; set delay tolerance to 1.
We want the video‑analytics batch jobs to run only after the network reaches off‑peak (after 8 pm), so the service can tolerate delays.
The smart‑meter readings can be stored locally and transmitted when the cell load drops below 20 % capacity, even if it takes up to 24 hours.
Please enable deterministic communication for the new slice; set Availability = 1.
The slice must provide guaranteed latency for PLC traffic, so deterministic communication must be supported.
Our video streaming service does not require strict timing; configure the slice without deterministic communication support.
Please configure the network slice to provide deterministic communication with a periodicity of exactly 200 seconds.
The slice must support deterministic messaging intervals of up to 350 seconds to meet our latency budget.
Our telemetry service sends data roughly every 4 minutes, so the slice should guarantee deterministic timing for that cadence.
Please configure the network slice with a guaranteed downlink throughput quota of 5000 kbps for all GBR traffic.
The slice must guarantee a minimum downlink rate of 2 Mbps for the aggregate GBR flows.
For the corporate slice, ensure the guaranteed downlink capacity can support 50 concurrent video‑conference streams, each needing 150 kbps.
Set the maximum downlink capacity for the enterprise slice to 150,000 kbps.
We need the slice serving video streaming to not exceed a total downlink rate of 200 Mbps across all users.
The new IoT slice must be limited so that the aggregate downlink traffic never goes beyond 0.1 Gbps.
Please configure the maximum downlink throughput per UE to 85,000 kbps.
For our premium subscriber class we need each user to get at least 65 Mbps downlink; set the per‑UE max accordingly.

The new live‑gaming service streams at 12 Mbps per player, and we must guarantee that no single UE exceeds its allocated downlink capacity; adjust the maximum downlink throughput per UE to match this requirement.
Please configure the 5G slice for our enterprise devices to use Service Category 2 as the downlink maximum throughput per UE.
For the enhanced mobile broadband (eMBB) slice, assign the medium‑throughput service tier so that each user equipment gets the appropriate downlink maximum throughput.
Our premium video streaming customers require the highest possible downlink capacity; set the UE downlink limit to the top service category in the network slice.
Please enable the Energy Efficiency KPI for our eMBB slice – it must be active (value 1).
In line with 3GPP Release 17, the slice has to satisfy the energy‑efficiency KPI, so set the KPI flag to indicate compliance.
Since the low‑power IoT slice already stays under the power‑per‑throughput limit, we want to turn off its energy‑efficiency KPI monitoring.
Configure this 5G slice to enable multicast group communication – we need value 1.
The slice must be able to broadcast emergency alerts to every device in the coverage area, so set the group‑communication mode accordingly.
For the vehicle‑to‑everything platooning service, the slice should let cars share synchronized status updates with the platoon leader and peers without opening separate unicast links.
Please configure the network slice so that its maximum supported packet size is 1500 bytes.
The slice should be able to transport full Ethernet frames without any fragmentation, which means the MTU must be at least the standard 1500‑byte payload.
For our URLLC services we need jumbo‑frame capability; the slice must handle packets up to 9 KB in size.
Please enable the mission‑critical flag for this slice; set it to 1.
We need this slice to be treated as high priority for both control‑plane and user‑plane decisions because it carries a mission‑critical service for our enterprise client.
The SLA for this slice requires no latency degradation under any congestion scenario, as it supports emergency response communications.
Please activate mission‑critical support with capability 1 enabled.
We require the network to support rapid failover for our emergency response units, which maps to capability 2.

The system must automatically switch traffic to a secondary route and maintain load balancing during any fault to keep mission‑critical applications running, implying both redundancy and load‑balancing capabilities.
Please configure this slice with mission‑critical support turned off – we don’t need any MC services (set it to 0).
We need this slice to carry mission‑critical push‑to‑talk traffic, so enable the appropriate MC support flag.
The public‑safety slice must interoperate with existing mission‑critical video and data streams, providing full MC functionality across all services.
Please enable MMTel on the new slice; we need it turned on (value 1).
The slice must be GSMA PRD NG.114 compliant for multimedia telephony, meaning MMTel must be present.
Since we are only offering basic circuit‑switched fallback, the slice should not include IMS/MMTel capabilities.
Please turn on NB‑IoT support for the new IoT slice; we need the NB‑IoT flag set to enabled.
The slice must serve low‑power, wide‑area sensors, so make sure NB‑IoT capability is active in the RAN.
For the upcoming high‑definition video streaming slice, do not allocate any NB‑IoT resources.
Please ensure that the Network Slice Customer supplies the UPF and UDM functions for our new eMBB slice.
For the upcoming private network slice, the client will handle core authentication and subscriber data, so we need the AUSF and UDM functions from them.
The slice will be entirely operated by the tenant, covering both data plane forwarding and all essential control plane services, leaving only the RAN under our control.
Please configure the slice to allow up to 120000 simultaneous PDU sessions.
The enterprise slice must be sized for roughly one hundred thousand concurrent PDU sessions during peak demand.
Considering roaming partners and local breakout traffic, we need the slice to handle the typical city‑wide load, which we estimate at about 250k active PDU sessions when EPS PDNs are included.
Enable EPS counting for the maximum number of PDU sessions; set the flag to 1.
The PDU‑session limit calculation should include PDN connections tied to the APN that maps to our slice's DNN/S‑NSSAI, so EPS counting must be turned on.
For this slice we do not want EPS‑based session accounting; the counter should ignore PDN links, i.e., EPS counting not required.
Please enable counting of LBO PDU sessions – set the flag to Yes.
For the upcoming release, we need the system to ignore LBO PDU sessions when calculating the max PDU sessions limit.
The capacity‑planning team wants the maximum PDU‑session metric to reflect only regular sessions, not any LBO‑initiated ones.
We need the slice to accommodate up to 100,000 UEs simultaneously.
The slice should be able to serve roughly 150k user equipments at peak hours, so set the maximum UE count accordingly.

For the upcoming stadium event, we anticipate a crowd of 70,000 spectators, each with a device, but only about 70% will be active on the network at any given moment; therefore, the slice must support the maximum simultaneous UEs required.
Activate EPS counting for UE statistics in this network slice – the flag should be set to 1.
For the slice we need to count only UEs that have at least one active PDN connection, so EPS counting must be enabled.
We do not want EPS‑based UE counting in this slice; only the basic UE count is required, so disable EPS counting.
Enable counting of roaming UEs in the maximum UE calculation.
Set the system so that roaming subscribers are not considered when enforcing the UE limit.
Our capacity policy only applies to domestic devices; any visited users should be excluded from the UE tally.
Please configure the slice to expose two availability KPIs for performance monitoring.
We require that the slice have at least one KQI for availability monitoring; otherwise the slice should be considered unsupported.
The network slice must include availability monitoring; if the list of KQIs/KPIs is empty, the slice's performance monitoring attribute should be disabled.
Please configure the performance monitoring sample frequency to 1 for our voice services.
We want the KQI measurements for our broadband offering to be collected on a half‑hourly basis.
According to our SLA, all NSP‑provided communication services must have their performance KPIs sampled as often as technically feasible, essentially continuous monitoring.
Please ensure the network slice includes the availability prediction KPI with identifier 2.
We require the slice to expose availability prediction for the first two KQIs, i.e., IDs 0 and 1.
The slice should support predictive analytics for all availability-related metrics, covering both baseline and advanced levels, which correspond to the full set of availability KPIs.
Please configure the system to deliver KPI prediction values once per hour.
We’d like the performance predictor to output forecasts twice daily, aligning with our morning and evening reviews.
During off‑peak periods the network should suppress any predictive KPI updates, only sending them when traffic exceeds 80% of capacity.
Please configure the slice to include GNSS and RTT positioning, i.e., methods 0 and 2.
We require the slice to expose OTDOA positioning capability; ensure the positioning set includes the corresponding identifier.
Since this slice will serve autonomous driving use‑cases, it must expose the full suite of positioning techniques supported by the network.
Please configure the positioning module so that the device can request location information at the highest allowed rate, i.e., set the prediction frequency to 2.
We need to cap location queries to roughly one request per second; adjust the positioning support to reflect a moderate prediction frequency.
For the new low‑cost plan, location data should only be available on an occasional basis, not continuously—set the prediction frequency accordingly.
Please configure the new URLLC slice to provide positioning accuracy of ±0.01 m.
The upcoming smart‑factory slice must keep the location error below one centimeter for robotic arm coordination.
Our drone delivery service demands that the positioning solution stay within a few centimeters error margin to ensure safe package drop zones.
Please allocate the slice to operate on the n77 band.
The slice must cover the 3.5 GHz mid‑band spectrum we currently use for enhanced mobile broadband.
Our legacy public‑safety devices only support the 2 GHz band, so the slice should be confined to that spectrum.
Please enable the highest level of monitoring and analytics (value 2) on the new 5G slice.
We require a basic telemetry interface exposed through the NEF so we can collect performance stats, but no deep analytics.
Our service guarantee mandates that any degradation be traceable; ensure the network supplies root‑cause analysis data via the exposure function.
Please set the Session and Service Continuity mode to 1 for all subscriber sessions so that the IP address is retained at all times.
Our policy requires that the UE keep its existing IP address during any mobility event, meaning the network must preserve the connectivity service.
We need the network to allow user‑plane changes without any perceived loss of service for the UE, even if the PDU session anchor moves and the IP address changes.
We need the new eMBB slice to allow concurrent usage with other slices; set its simultaneous use class to 1.
The upcoming URLLC slice must be shareable with the existing massive IoT slice, but not with any other services. Assign the appropriate simultaneous‑use class.

Our network will run a mixed‑traffic slice for premium customers that should operate alongside best‑effort traffic without any performance degradation. Ensure the slice’s simultaneous use setting reflects full coexistence.
Please configure the UE to use Service Category 2 for simultaneous slice usage.
The device must be placed in the same simultaneous‑use class as our high‑priority video streaming group, which is mapped to Service Category 3 in the policy table.
We need this subscriber to have the same concurrent service capabilities as the enterprise broadband tier; according to our configuration, that corresponds to Service Category 1.
Assign 5QI 2 to the new video streaming slice.
Create a URLLC slice for factory automation and use the 5QI that provides the strictest latency and reliability guarantees.
Set up a massive IoT slice with the least stringent QoS requirements, using the appropriate 5QI.
Please set the Resource Type to 0 for the custom 5QI value we have chosen.
We need a semi‑permanent allocation for the GFBR on this slice, so apply the appropriate Resource Type.
Our SLA demands that the guaranteed flow bit rate is always exclusively allocated, never shared with other traffic – select the Resource Type that guarantees permanent resources.
Please configure the priority level of the 5G slice dedicated to video streaming to 30.
For our mission‑critical IoT slice we want the second‑highest scheduling priority, which should correspond to a priority level of 5.
Assign the ultra‑reliable low‑latency traffic the utmost scheduling precedence over all other traffic in the network.
Set the packet delay budget for 5QI 9 to 20 ms for both uplink and downlink.
We need to guarantee that the end‑to‑end latency on the N6 interface does not exceed 30 ms for the low‑latency slice, so configure the PDB accordingly.
Our new AR/VR service requires the minimum possible latency; please configure the scheduling parameters so that the packet delay budget is effectively disabled.
Please configure the URLLC slice (5QI 85) so that the packet error rate never exceeds 0.00001.
For the eMBB service using 5QI 78, the PER must be kept below one‑thousandth of the transmitted packets.
In our delay‑critical GBR flow (5QI 46), packets arriving later than the PDB count as lost; the total PER—including these late packets—has to stay under two‑hundredths of a percent.
Please configure the averaging window for the GBR QoS flow to 100 ms.
For 5QI value 78 we require a non‑default averaging window of 250 ms to calculate GFBR and MFBR.
Our ultra‑reliable low‑latency slice should compute the guaranteed bitrate over a very brief interval, roughly 0.05 seconds.
Please configure the Maximum Data Burst Volume for the GBR QoS flow (5QI=85) to exactly 1 048 576 bytes.
For our delay‑critical slice we require that the network can deliver up to approximately 2 MiB of data within the 5G‑AN PDB; set the MDBV accordingly.

The new industrial automation service must limit any burst to only a few megabytes per PDB interval to keep buffer overruns down; use the minimal non‑default burst size that satisfies this, i.e., the smallest standard MDBV above zero.
Please allocate a guaranteed downlink flow bit rate of 3000 kbps for the GBR slice supporting voice over LTE.
The GBR QoS flow for the IoT slice must guarantee at least 1.5 Mbps downlink, so set the GFBR‑DL accordingly.
For the premium video‑on‑demand slice we need to sustain 1080p streaming at 30 fps, which requires roughly 4.8 Mbps downlink; configure the guaranteed flow bit rate to cover this demand.
Please configure the GBR slice to guarantee an uplink flow bit rate of 5,000 kbps.
We need the guaranteed uplink bandwidth for the GBR QoS flow to be at least 2 Mbps to support our voice‑over‑LTE services.
The slice must sustain a high‑definition video uplink stream (1080p@30 fps), which translates to roughly a 3 Mbps guaranteed flow rate.
Please configure the downlink maximum flow bit rate for the GBR QoS flow to 5 Mbps.
We require a guaranteed downlink throughput of 2 Mbps for the video streaming slice, so set the MFBR‑DL accordingly.
For the IoT sensor slice, the downlink MFBR should be about one‑tenth of the uplink rate, which is 2 Mbps.
Please configure the GBR flow's uplink maximum bit rate to 2500 kbps.
For the 5QI=85 slice, the uplink capacity must not exceed 4 Mbps.
Our new IoT telemetry service needs to handle bursty uplink traffic up to 12 megabits per second for critical alerts, so set the MFBR accordingly.
Set the maximum packet loss rate for both uplink and downlink voice GBR flows to 0 %.
The network should limit the downlink packet loss for voice GBR traffic to no more than one lost packet per hundred packets.
According to our SLA, the voice slice must keep packet loss below the 2 % ceiling stipulated for high‑priority conversational services.
Please turn on non‑IP traffic support on the new edge routers; we need it enabled (value 1).
The upcoming deployment must allow Ethernet‑only sessions to be forwarded without IP encapsulation, so make sure the devices have non‑IP session support active.
Our plant's control network still runs on raw Ethernet frames; the replacement switches have to handle that traffic, otherwise the SCADA link will break.
The new ultra‑reliable low‑latency slice must be capable of supporting devices moving at up to 2 km/h while preserving the defined QoS and seamless handover.
We need a slice that can keep the connection stable for cyclists, so the supported device speed should be roughly 1 km/h to satisfy the QoS requirements across different RATs.
The network slice should guarantee uninterrupted service for stationary IoT sensors, with only occasional foot traffic, implying a supported device velocity of essentially 0 km/h.
Please configure the PC5 synchronicity availability to 0.
We require a basic level of device synchronization over PC5 when the core network is unavailable, so set the availability to the low‑sync option.
The system must maintain timing coordination between all UE devices regardless of any network outage, effectively treating PC5 as continuously available for synchronization.
Please configure the synchronicity accuracy to 0.000001 seconds.
The system must keep the time drift under 1 millisecond.
Our SLA requires that the clock skew never exceeds 5 microseconds.
We need the slice to support up to 50,000 devices per square kilometre.
The target deployment area should be able to handle a density of at least 2×10⁵ users per km².
We anticipate 3 million IoT sensors spread across a 10 km² industrial park, requiring the slice to sustain the sensor density.
Please allocate a guaranteed uplink throughput of 5,000 kbps for the new IoT network slice.
The enterprise slice must provide at least 2 Mbps of uplink capacity for all GBR QoS flows combined.
Our video‑surveillance slice should sustain a minimum uplink floor that can carry ten HD camera streams, each requiring 300 kbps, without degradation.
Please configure the maximum uplink throughput for the enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB) slice to 150000 kbps.
The upcoming massive IoT slice should guarantee a minimum aggregate uplink capacity of 75 Mbps for all connected devices.
For the ultra‑reliable low‑latency communications (URLLC) slice, we need to provision enough uplink bandwidth to handle peak bursts of 0.2 Gbps across the slice.
Please configure the network so that each UE's maximum uplink throughput is limited to 1800 kbps.
The uplink capacity per user equipment should be capped at 2 Mbps.
According to the service category for Category 3 devices, the uplink should not surpass the 1.1 Mbps ceiling per UE.
Please configure the uplink maximum throughput for all IoT devices in Slice A to use Service Category 2.
For the video‑streaming network slice we require the highest uplink throughput tier that the system offers; assign the corresponding service category.
The low‑latency slice serving autonomous‑vehicle telemetry should be limited to a moderate uplink bandwidth level—neither the lowest nor the top tier—so pick the appropriate service class.
Enable user management openness for the slice so we can add, modify, or delete users as needed.
The network slice should let us control which of our subscriber base can access it, meaning we must be able to assign or revoke users on the fly.
We require a static allocation where the slice is bound to a predetermined list of devices and no further user changes are permitted after provisioning.
Configure the new CPE to provide direct Internet connectivity; set the data network access option to the value that represents unrestricted Internet access.
The customer requires all user traffic to be routed through a secure VPN tunnel back to their private data center, so the data network access should reflect termination in a private network.

We need a fully isolated deployment where none of the subscriber equipment can reach either the public Internet or any external private network; everything must stay inside the operator’s own core network.
Configure the private data network termination to use tunnelling mechanism 1.
Set the data network access to use the GTP-C tunnelling method for LTE interworking.
Since the private network will handle termination of data sessions, apply the default tunnelling configuration.
Please enable the data network access for Local Breakout while the subscriber is roaming.
We need to make sure that roaming users cannot use the local breakout data path, effectively disabling it.
The policy should prevent any data traffic from being routed locally when the device is on a visited network, so LBO must be turned off for roaming sessions.
Please set the V2X‑PC5 network slice to operate in scheduled mode – use the value 1 for this attribute.
Our upcoming V2X service will run without any PC5 scheduling; it should behave as a best‑effort slice, so the scheduled‑mode flag must be disabled.
For the safety‑critical platooning use case we need deterministic latency on the PC5 interface, therefore the slice must be provisioned with the highest level of PC5 scheduling support.
Please set the default NR PC5 communication mode to 1 for the network‑scheduled PC5 operation.
Configure the PC5 scheduled mode to use the third option defined for NR PC5 defaults.
Our V2X rollout needs the primary NR PC5 mode that handles scheduled broadcasts without LTE fallback.
We need the slice to guarantee a maximum one‑way latency of 2 ms between the last UPF and the application server.
The service must keep the latency from the final UPF to the backend server below 7 ms for all traffic.
The slice must guarantee that the one‑way delay from the final UPF to the application server stays within a 1‑3 ms window, with the upper bound defining the slice's latency guarantee.
Enable Network Slice Specific Authentication and Authorization for the upcoming eMBB slice; set the flag to 1.
For the new URLLC slice, we must enforce an extra AAA check beyond the standard subscriber authentication.
The slice we are provisioning for IoT devices will rely solely on the existing SIM‑based authentication; no additional AAA validation is needed.
Please turn on Multimedia Priority Service for the new video‑conferencing VLAN.
We need all streaming media traffic to be treated with higher precedence than regular data traffic on the campus backbone.
Run a baseline test with no priority for multimedia streams; keep MPS turned off during the experiment.
Please turn on Multimedia Priority Service and set its capability flag to 1.
Configure the MPS to support both low‑latency and high‑throughput modes, i.e., enable capabilities 0 and 1.
The operator requires full multimedia priority handling for voice and video streams, so all MPS capabilities should be activated.
Configure this network slice to support Multimedia Priority Service for MMTel voice only – set the MPS flag to 1.
The slice should prioritize both MMTel voice and video traffic, while data traffic can remain best‑effort; assign the appropriate MPS setting.
We need a generic data‑only slice with no priority handling for any MMTel services, effectively disabling Multimedia Priority Service.
Please provision the slice to use the LTE data network named 'PublicNet'.
The new slice must connect to both the corporate IoT network and the public broadband service, which are identified as CorpIoTNet and PublicBroadband.
All user equipment in this slice should be restricted to the carrier's 5G core and the backup LTE fallback, without mentioning the network names directly.
Please set the UE's service category to Service Category 1.
The subscriber should be treated as a premium user, so assign the corresponding service category from the supported data networks list.
For all IoT devices on the network, we need to apply the default low‑bandwidth data profile defined in our supported data networks.
We need to support up to 100,000 UEs that have at least one active PDU session or PDN connection on this slice.
The slice should be sized to handle roughly twice our present subscriber load, which translates to about 250,000 devices each maintaining at least one PDU/PDN connection.

Our architecture must not limit the slice when the network reaches its theoretical maximum UE density – about one million users could be simultaneously attached, each with at least one PDU session tied to the slice’s APN.
Please enable V2X‑PC5 parameter provisioning on our 5G core and set the attribute to 1.
Our V2X service requires full control‑plane provisioning for both NR and LTE PC5 interfaces; configure the V2X‑PC5 provisioning attribute accordingly.
We want to prohibit any over‑the‑air parameter updates on the PC5 link for V2X devices, effectively disabling control‑plane provisioning.
Please turn on PDU set support for the XR video service so that all PDUs belonging to a single frame are handled together within the same QoS flow.
We require the transport to treat the collection of PDUs that compose one XR slice as a single unit; make sure the network processes them with per‑PDU‑set granularity.
For the telemetry stream, handle each packet independently and do not group them; the network should ignore any relationship between successive PDUs.

For our upcoming global FPS tournament we need the network to deliver round‑trip latency of no more than 15 ms, jitter under 2 ms, packet loss below 0.1 % and an availability of 99.99 % during the event window, otherwise players will experience unfair lag spikes.

Our mobile battle‑royale title can tolerate an average latency of 30 ms and a maximum jitter of 10 ms, but we still need the service to be up at least 99.5 % of the time to keep the player base engaged during peak evenings.
The cloud‑gaming platform must keep end‑to‑end latency under 20 ms and packet loss below 0.05 % to avoid visual artifacts, while delivering 99.9 % availability 24/7 for our subscribers.

Our casual MMO can operate with latency up to 50 ms and jitter as high as 15 ms, and we can accept packet loss up to 0.2 %; a 99 % availability target is sufficient for the long‑running world sessions.

The esports training lab needs ultra‑low jitter—below 1 ms—and latency around 10 ms to keep replay synchronization exact; packet loss must be essentially zero (0 %) and we require five‑nine availability (99.999 %) to avoid any interruption during practice sessions.

For our remote robotic surgery platform we must guarantee an end‑to‑end latency of no more than 10 ms and a reliability of 99.9999 % so that the surgeon’s commands are executed instantly and without error.
Our Tele‑ICU video monitoring service must be up 99.999 % of the time, 24 hours a day, because any downtime could mean missing a life‑critical alarm.

When we transfer high‑resolution patient imaging between facilities we need encryption at least AES‑256 (256‑bit key) and SHA‑256 integrity, while keeping latency under 30 ms to avoid delaying diagnosis.

The remote laparoscopic system requires network jitter below 2 ms and packet loss under 0.001 %, plus an overall availability of 99.999 % and reliability of 99.9999 % to ensure precise instrument control.

Our tele‑rehabilitation platform should maintain at least 99.9 % availability and latency no greater than 50 ms, and must enforce multi‑factor authentication (OTP + biometric) for every clinician login to protect patient data.

Our conveyor‑belt synchronization must keep the command latency under 5 ms and stay online at least 99.99% of the time, otherwise the product feed will drift and cause mis‑alignment on the assembly line.
The robotic welding cells need to exchange status updates every 10 ms cycle with a reliability of 99.999% so that any missed command could produce a weld defect and increase scrap rates.
For furnace temperature monitoring a latency of roughly 8 ms is acceptable, but the sensor network must be available at least 99.9% during a 12‑hour shift to avoid blind spots in the control loop.
The vision inspection line cannot tolerate more than 0.001% packet loss and needs jitter below 2 ms; otherwise the high‑speed defect detection algorithm will miss fast‑moving parts.

Predictive‑maintenance data from the CNC machines can handle up to 15 ms latency, but we require the data feed to be at least 99.95% available so the analytics engine sees a continuous trend and can schedule service before a failure.

For highway platooning we need ultra‑low latency and ultra‑high reliability so that a string of autonomous trucks can keep a 2‑meter gap at 100 km/h; the V2X link must deliver packets in ≤ 5 ms with 99.9999 % reliability and provide vehicle positioning within 10 cm using the C‑V2X interface.

When pushing OTA firmware updates to the fleet we can tolerate higher latency, but we still need the link to be dependable; a maximum round‑trip delay of 100 ms and at least 99.9 % reliability over the cellular V2X channel is sufficient for this use case.

At busy city intersections our cooperative crossing service must react quickly; we require V2X messages to arrive within 20 ms with 99.999 % reliability and the vehicle’s position to be known to within 30 cm so that the controller can safely grant right‑of‑way.

For emergency‑brake warning broadcasts we need the fastest possible reaction; the warning must be transmitted in ≤ 2 ms with a reliability of 99.99999 % to ensure downstream vehicles can brake in time, using the low‑latency DSRC spectrum.

High‑definition map creation requires precise geolocation; we need positioning accuracy of 5 cm, can accept up to 50 ms latency, and need at least 99.99 % reliability on the C‑V2X link to upload sensor data reliably.

We need to support 4K live streaming at 60 fps during peak hours, so each network slice must deliver at least 45 Mbps downlink, keep jitter under 20 ms, and maintain 99.95 % availability to avoid viewer drop‑outs.

Our video‑on‑demand catalog offers 1080p content, so we expect an average downlink throughput of around 25 Mbps, jitter not exceeding 30 ms, and overall availability of 99.9 % to keep buffering under 2 seconds.

For high‑stakes sports events we must guarantee a dedicated slice that can sustain 50 Mbps downlink, jitter below 15 ms, and 99.99 % availability for the two‑hour broadcast window to prevent any lag or interruptions.
For our mobile audience we can tolerate a lower floor: at least 15 Mbps downlink, jitter up to 50 ms is acceptable, and we need 99.5 % availability to keep playback smooth on handheld devices.

Premium subscribers expect the best experience, so we must provision a slice capable of peak downlink throughput of 80 Mbps, jitter under 10 ms, and an ultra‑high availability of 99.999 % to meet SLA commitments.

We need the cellular layer to accommodate 1,200,000 smart‑meter endpoints that can move at up to 5 km/h – these meters are installed on service trucks that drive through the field, so the network must stay reliable even when the devices are in motion.

Our downtown deployment of environmental sensors will pack roughly 1.5 million user‑equipment (UE) per square kilometre; we cannot afford any packet loss during the rush‑hour reporting window, so the network must sustain that UE density continuously.

We plan to roll out 500,000 agricultural sensors across a 200 km² region – an average density of about 2,500 devices per km² – but during harvest we expect short‑term spikes up to 10,000 devices per km² when all sensors transmit soil‑moisture data simultaneously.

For our fleet of inspection drones we need to support 300,000 high‑velocity terminals moving as fast as 120 km/h, because they stream live video back to the control centre while inspecting bridges and power lines; any lag would make the footage unusable.

Our utility company will maintain a steady base of 1,000,000 static meters with a UE density of 1,000,000 per km², but we must also survive brief firmware‑update windows where the density can surge to 1.3 million per km² without service degradation.

Our SCADA system must stay online almost all the time – we need at least 99.99% availability – and any control command has to reach the field devices within 20 ms, otherwise the grid could become unstable during rapid load changes.

For the phasor measurement units we require sub‑microsecond timing accuracy, specifically 1 µs synchronization, and the data stream must be reliable at the 99.999% level so that fault location algorithms can trust the measurements.

Demand‑response signals can tolerate a bit more delay, but we still need the messaging service to be up 99.9% of the time and latency should not exceed 100 ms, otherwise customers won’t react quickly enough to price signals.
Protective relays require ultra‑fast and ultra‑reliable links: we need end‑to‑end latency under 5 ms and an availability of 99.9999% so that trips are executed without missing a fault.

When we push firmware updates to remote substations we can accept higher latency – up to 500 ms – but the transfer must succeed at least 99.95% of the time and the overall reliability of the update session should be no less than 99.9% to avoid bricking devices.

We need the primary exchange gateway to deliver order entry latency of no more than 1 ms and jitter under 0.1 ms, while keeping the link up at least 99.999% of the time, because any extra delay or variability directly erodes our price‑time advantage in the market.

Our market‑data feed must stay under 0.8 ms latency with jitter below 0.05 ms; we can tolerate a slightly lower availability of 99.99% for this secondary feed, since rapid reaction to price changes is critical for our trading algorithms.

The order‑routing engine must achieve at least 99.999% uptime; during peak trading hours its latency budget can stretch to 1.2 ms, and jitter should stay under 0.2 ms, to ensure continuous compliance reporting and avoid missed execution opportunities.

For our co‑located matching engine we target a latency of 0.5 ms and jitter under 0.05 ms, with an ultra‑high availability of at least 99.9999% (six‑nines), because even a microsecond advantage can be the difference between profit and loss in latency‑arbitrage strategies.

Our overnight batch‑processing network can operate with up to 5 ms latency and jitter as high as 1 ms, provided the overall availability stays above 99.9%, since this traffic is non‑critical and can tolerate a bit more delay.

Our dispatch centre must keep the core public‑safety slice up 99.999 % of the time, be treated as priority 1 traffic, and be able to carry at least 1 000 simultaneous MMTel voice calls so that call takers never lose a line during a major incident.

For ambulance telemetry we can tolerate a slightly lower uptime of 99.99 %, but the slice still needs to be priority 2 and must support MMTel video streams of at least 5 Mbps each to transmit live patient vitals to the hospital.

The fire department’s command units require the network slice to be available 99.999 % of the time and to be classified as priority 1 so that any loss of connectivity would immediately trigger backup radio fallback.

Police patrol cars need MMTel SMS capability that can handle at least 200 messages per second, must run on a priority 1 slice, and the slice’s availability should not drop below 99.999 % to ensure rapid dissemination of alerts.

Our search‑and‑rescue drones rely on an MMTel data channel that can sustain at least 10 Mbps of uplink bandwidth, operate on a priority 3 slice, and keep the slice up 99.9 % of the time so that video feeds aren’t interrupted during critical missions.

We need reliable 5G coverage over roughly 300 km² of our crop fields so that our fleet of monitoring drones can stream high‑resolution video back to the control centre in real time for pest detection and yield estimation.

Our irrigation district spans about 12 000 ha and we must guarantee at least 95 % network availability for the 2 000 low‑power soil‑moisture sensors that will run continuously throughout the growing season.

During harvest we plan to run up to 150 autonomous tractors on a 50 km² plot and need the network to support all of them simultaneously without latency spikes that could affect steering and safety systems.
We are looking for a broadband solution that can deliver at least 20 Mbps downlink to the main farm office and the nearby farmer cooperative, covering a radius of about 15 km from our central hub.

Our network must be resilient enough to handle a network of weather stations spread across 200 km², each sending roughly 10 MB of data per hour, with a target density of at least 10 stations per 20 km² to ensure fine‑grained micro‑climate monitoring.

Our automated guided vehicles that stack containers need real‑time position updates within 5 cm and a control‑loop latency no greater than 8 ms, otherwise the stacking algorithm will miss its target and cause costly re‑work. We also require the network to be up 99.99 % of the time to keep the yard operating continuously.

The remote sensors on our quay cranes can tolerate a positioning error of up to 15 cm, but the command feedback must arrive within 20 ms to avoid swing‑over during container lifts, and we need a packet‑loss rate below 0.1 % to keep the safety system reliable.

For drone‑based hull inspections we require sub‑centimetre positioning – ideally 2 cm – and ultra‑low latency under 5 ms so the live video feed stays synchronized with the navigation system; the link must also achieve 99.999 % reliability to prevent any data gaps during the inspection pass.

Our yard‑management software aggregates GPS data from dozens of RFID readers; a positioning tolerance of 10 cm is sufficient, but we need the updates to be delivered within 15 ms to keep the real‑time map accurate, and an overall network uptime of at least 99.5 % to avoid gaps in inventory tracking.

The temperature sensors in our refrigerated containers only need to report every few minutes, so a latency tolerance of up to 100 ms is fine, but we still expect the network to deliver at least 99 % of the packets to ensure we catch any temperature excursions promptly.

For the upcoming international concert we expect roughly 80,000 fan devices to be connected simultaneously, and each network slice allocated to the event must be able to deliver up to 800 Mbps of downlink throughput so that live‑streaming, AR overlays, and ticket‑validation apps run without buffering.

During the championship game the stadium will host a full capacity crowd of 100,000 attendees; we need the core slice to support a peak downlink capacity of 1 Gbps and an auxiliary slice for broadcast crews that must stay under 30 ms latency to ensure real‑time video feeds and instant replays.

The VIP lounges will accommodate about 5,000 premium guests who will be using 4K video streaming and high‑resolution photo sharing; each slice serving the lounges must guarantee at least 200 Mbps of downlink throughput.

For safety and emergency response we need a dedicated slice that can reliably serve up to 10,000 handheld devices used by staff and first‑responders, with a guaranteed minimum downlink capacity of 500 Mbps to ensure real‑time video and telemetry transmission.

The mobile ordering system for concessions must handle roughly 30,000 terminals; each slice should provide at least 100 Mbps of downlink, but we would like the ability to scale up to 200 Mbps during peak intermission periods when order volumes spike.

Our point‑of‑sale terminals must stay online at least 99.9% of the time, otherwise customers will see checkout lines build up, and each network slice dedicated to the stores needs to deliver a minimum of 50 Mbps downlink so that video analytics for shopper behavior run without buffering.

The IoT temperature and inventory tags scattered across the floor have to report data reliably, so we need at least 99.5% availability and a 5 Mbps downlink per slice, plus end‑to‑end AES‑256 encryption to protect the data from tampering.

Our loyalty app pushes personalized offers in real time; any lag drops conversion, so we require a downlink capacity of 100 Mbps per slice, latency no greater than 30 ms, and 99.95% availability to keep the experience seamless.

Self‑checkout kiosks must never go offline during peak hours, so we need 99.9% availability, TLS encryption with at least 128‑bit strength for payment data, and a 20 Mbps downlink slice to handle receipt printing and over‑the‑air firmware updates.

Our digital signage network across 30 stores streams 4K video, so each slice must provide at least 200 Mbps downlink and 99.8% availability, and we need strict slice isolation to guarantee that promotional content isn’t throttled by other traffic.
We need the whole campus Wi‑Fi to be available at least 99.5% of the time so that live lecture streams never drop, because any interruption could affect accreditation reviews.

For the science building’s remote lab simulations we must guarantee a maximum downlink throughput of 250 Mbps per network slice and keep availability at 99%, otherwise high‑resolution data sets will time out and experiments will be delayed.

During peak library hours each student device should be able to pull at least 100 Mbps downlink so that research PDFs and video tutorials load instantly; we’re okay with roughly 95% availability because occasional brief dips are tolerable in a study environment.

Administrative staff need a reliable VPN connection campus‑wide with 99% availability and at least 50 Mbps downlink per slice so that email, payroll and HR portals stay responsive throughout the workday.

During exam season the examination hall must have a guaranteed 200 Mbps downlink per slice and 99.9% availability to ensure the online proctoring platform runs without lag, preventing any opportunity for cheating caused by network delays.

We need uninterrupted wireless coverage along the entire 3 km of main haulage tunnels, with a minimum availability of 99.95%, so that remote‑controlled drilling rigs can stay online without costly downtime.

For worker safety we require positioning support that can locate each person within 0.3 m and deliver that location update in under 20 ms, so that emergency shutdowns can be triggered instantly if someone enters a hazardous zone.
The main ore‑extraction level must have redundant coverage – at least two independent signal paths – to guarantee 99.9% availability even when maintenance crews are working on the primary equipment.

Our seismic monitoring system needs a minimum data throughput of 5 Mbps per sensor node, and the network must reach every side gallery up to 150 m from the main shaft, so high‑resolution waveforms can be streamed in real time.

Autonomous haul trucks must be tracked with positioning error no greater than 0.8 m while traveling up to 10 km/h, because any larger error could cause route‑planning conflicts and increase collision risk.
Our esports tournament needs a seamless experience for 10,000 concurrent players worldwide.
We need the backup link to be twice as fast as the current 200 Mbps MPLS line.
We demand an ultra‑reliable connection for our autonomous drone fleet that can tolerate zero packet loss.
Deploy a video streaming service for our mobile app.
Provide a URLLC‑grade slice for our Industry 4.0 robotic assembly line, supporting 1 ms latency and 99.9999% availability.
Our remote surgery platform must be at least 30 % faster than the 50 ms latency we currently experience.
Need a 'rock‑solid' network for real‑time financial trading.
Set up a MEC edge compute node for V2X communications, ensuring 5G NR sub‑6 GHz coverage with a target end‑to‑end latency of 10 ms for safety messages.
Our AR collaboration tool should feel smoother than our current 60 fps video chat, targeting 'fluid' performance.
We want a 'green' network for our data center interconnect.
We need a gaming network that feels buttery smooth for 4K 120 fps streaming on consoles across the house.
Our new branch office must experience latency at least 20 % lower than the 50 ms we currently see on the legacy VPN.
We need an ultra‑reliable connection for our mission‑critical drone fleet that can tolerate any single link failure without dropping packets.
Our video streaming service must run smoothly on mobile devices.
Deploy a URLLC‑grade service for our factory automation line that requires deterministic latency under 1 ms and 99.9999 % reliability.
The new remote‑learning platform should feel faster than the 30 ms round‑trip we see on our campus Wi‑Fi, especially during live quizzes.
Our corporate VPN must be rock‑solid, providing a silky experience even when the network is under heavy load.
We want to support 4K video calls for up to 25 participants on a satellite link.
Set up a Time‑Sensitive Networking (TSN) slice for the robotic arm line that guarantees sub‑microsecond synchronization and can survive a single switch failure without missing a control cycle.

Our edge‑AI inference nodes must process sensor streams in near real‑time, meaning the end‑to‑end delay should be indistinguishable from the sensor's native 5 ms sampling period, even when the link is congested.
